author: Ben Horne
title: Ashes 2015: Joe Root motivated by pain of earlier Aussie humiliation | The
text:
ENGLAND batsman Joe Root admits being dropped for the fifth Test of the last Ashes series was the motivating factor behind his record-busting knock in Cardiff on Wednesday.
Root’s 118-ball ton was the fastest century ever scored on the first day of an Ashes Test, in an emphatic performance that completely changed the momentum of play.
Australia dominated Root so comprehensively 18 months ago that the baby-faced Yorkshireman’s Test career was on the ropes by the end.
VERDICT: Tough day for Aussie bowlers
LIVE BLOG: How the day unfolded
MATCH CENTRE: First Test scorecard
COSTLY: The drop that cost Australia
But there is little doubt now that Root has now developed into one of the best batsmen in world cricket, as he gave the home side the dream start — with the first hundred scored by an Englishman to open an Ashes series since 1938.
“He’s the most improved player from last time we saw him and played against him,” Australian quick Josh Hazlewood said of Root.
“So we’ll have to work out a way to get him out.
“Just his patience really (was most impressive). He really waited for that bad ball throughout the whole day.”
Haddin lets go of Root 0:49 Play video
The Ashes: Brad Haddin has let Joe Root off the hook as Mitchell Starc begins to find his groove in the first session.
Fox Sports 08 Jul 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes Root’s 134 was his second Ashes hundred and the seventh of a blossoming career where he already averages over 50 from his 27 Tests.
He came to the crease with England reeling at 3-43, but despite giving a chance when on nought, Root refused to be tied down and took the fight to Australia with 17 fours.
Root has gone from Australia’s bunny to their worst nightmare.
“There are going to be opportunities to score because they’re going to have aggressive fields,” said Root.
“It could have gone completely the other way and got out second ball and you look a bit silly.
“First of all (the motivation after being dropped from the last Ashes) was to get back into the side and then contribute as much as I could.
“It was a feeling I don’t want to ever go through again but in this sport you have to deal with hard times and show a lot of self-belief and self-confidence to overcome them.”
England's Joe Root kisses the badge in his helmet as he celebrates a century applauded by Australia's Shane Watson, left, and Brad Haddin. Source: AP
Root scored two hundreds in the recent ODI series against New Zealand as well as a 98 in the first Test against the Black Caps.
His only previous Ashes hundred came in eerily similar circumstances, when he gave a chance through slips on 8 only to go on and post 180 in England’s giant second Test win at Lord’s back in 2013.
Root praised the grit shown by under-fire No. 3 Gary Ballance (61) to weather an early storm as the Yorkshire pair combined for a crucial 153-run stand.
He said it was too early to write off Mitchell Johnson despite his slow start to the series.
